pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pj: The rules in this category are known in Pali as _pārājika_. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the monastic Sangha. There are eight such rules for the nuns, four of which are shared with the monks. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses her status as a nun. She is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of her life. The _pārājikas_, together with the next category of rules, the _saṅghādisesas_, are collectively known as serious offenses, _garukāpatti_. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pj1: A nun who voluntarily has sexual intercourse is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pj2: A nun who steals anything of value is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pj3: A nun who kills a human being is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pj4: A nun who falsely claims a profound spiritual attainment is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pj5: A lustful nun who agrees to a lustful man touching her anywhere below the collar bone and above the knees is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pj6: A nun who does not take any action when she knows that another nun has committed an offense entailing expulsion is expelled. This is the first among a large of rules in which the notorious nun Thullanandā was the original offender. Either Thullanandā was an exceptionally bad nun or she is a literary stand-in for the real offenders.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pj7: A nun who persistently sides with a monk who has been legitimately ejected is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pj8: A nun who agrees to all of eight kinds of flirtatious behavior is expelled. This is the first among a large number of rules that features the notorious group of six nuns. These nuns were possibly affiliated with the group of six monks, or they are modelled on them.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-ss: The rules in this category are known in Pali as _saṅghādisesa_. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (_ādi_) and for the rest (_sesa_) of the procedure. There are seventeen such rules for the nuns, seven of which are shared with the monks. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-ss1: A nun who uses litigation inappropriately is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-ss2: A nun who ordains a female criminal sentenced to death is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-np: The rules in this category are known in Pali as _nissaggiya pācittiya_, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the nuns, the same number as for the monks, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, _lahukāpatti_. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the _nissaggiya pācittiyas_, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender.

This rule also prescribes the procedure through which a lay follower comes to hold money on behalf of a donor who wishes to support a nun.

These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, _lahukāpatti_. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.

pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc104: A nun who tells an unordained person about her own profound spiritual attainment must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc105: A nun who tells an unordained person about another nun’s serious offense must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc106: A nun who digs the earth must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc107: A nun who intentionally destroys vegetation must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc108: A nun who speaks evasively or remains silent when questioned by the Order must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc109: A nun who criticizes or denounces an official of the Order must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc110: A nun who abandons furniture belonging to the Order outdoors must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc111: A nun who abandons bedding in a dwelling belonging to the Order must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc112: A nun who lies down in a dwelling belonging to the Order, encroaching on another nun and aiming to make her depart, must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc113: A nun who throws another nun out of a dwelling belonging to the Order must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc114: A nun who uses a bed with unfastened legs on an unplanked upper storey of a hut belonging to the Order must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc115: A nun who applies more than three layers of building material when building a large dwelling must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc116: A nun who pours water containing living beings onto the ground must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc117: A nun who eats more than one meal at a public alms center must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc118: A nun who eats as part of a specifically invited group of nuns must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc119: A nun who accepts more than three bowlfuls of pastries must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc120: A nun who eats between noon and dawn must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc121: A nun who eats food stored overnight must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc122: A nun who consumes unoffered food or drink must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc123: A nun who takes another nun on almsround, but then tells her to leave because she wants to misbehave must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc124: A nun who sits down intruding on a lustful couple must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc125: A nun who sits in a secluded place with a man must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc126: A nun who sits in private with a man must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc127: A nun who visits other lay people before or after an invitational meal must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc128: A nun who goes beyond the terms of an invitation to ask for requisites must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc129: A nun who goes to see an army in action must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc130: A nun who stays with an army for more than three nights must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc131: If, while staying with an army, a nun goes to see the army in action, she must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc132: A nun who consumes alcohol must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc133: A nun who tickles another nun must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc134: A nun who plays in water must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc135: A nun who is disrespectful when rightly corrected about a breach of the monastic code must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc136: A nun who frightens another nun must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc137: A nun who lights a fire to warm herself must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc138: A nun in the central Ganges plain who bathes more than once a fortnight, except when dirty, must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc139: A nun who wears a new robe without first marking it must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc140: A nun who uses robe-cloth that has been transferred to a fellow monastic must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc141: A nun who hides the requisites of another nun must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc142: A nun who intentionally kills a living being must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc143: A nun who uses water that contains living beings must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc144: A nun who tries to reopen an issue of monastic law that has been properly settled must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc145: A nun who travels by arrangement with thieves must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc146: A nun who says that things declared as obstructive by the Buddha are not actually obstructive must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc147: A nun who lives with a nun who has been ejected for holding the view that things declared as obstructive by the Buddha are not actually obstructive must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc148: A nun who lives with a novice nun who has been expelled for holding the view that things declared as obstructive by the Buddha are not actually obstructive must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc149: A nun who uses a ploy as an excuse for not keeping the monastic code must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc150: A nun who criticizes the monastic code must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc151: A nun who deceptively claims that she did not know a rule in the monastic code must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc152: A nun who in anger strikes another nun must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc153: A nun who in anger physically threatens another nun must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc154: A nun who falsely accuses another nun of an offense entailing suspension must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc155: A nun who intentionally makes another nun anxious must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc156: A nun who eavesdrops on other nuns who are disputing about the Teaching or the monastic law must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc157: A nun who has given her consent for the Order to perform an official act, but then criticizes the act must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc158: A nun who departs without giving her consent while the Order is deciding on an issue must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc159: If a nun, acting as part of a complete Order, gives away a robe to an official of the Order, but then criticizes the act, she must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc160: A nun who diverts to an individual an offering intended for the Order must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc161: A nun who picks up anything considered valuable must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc162: A nun who makes a needle-case of bone, ivory, or horn must destroy it and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc163: A nun who makes a bed with long legs must shorten them and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc164: A nun who makes a bed with luxurious upholstery must remove the upholstery and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc165: A nun who makes a bandage that is too large must cut it down and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pc166: A nun who makes a robe that is too large must cut it down and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-pd: The rules in this category are known in Pali as _pāṭidesanīya_, “entailing acknowledgement”. There are eight such rules for the nuns. These eight rules for the nuns are equivalent to a single rule for the monks (_bhikkhu-pācittiya_ 39). In summary, they say that a nun who asks for special food must acknowledge the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-sk: The rules in this category are known in Pali as _sekhiya_, “involving training”. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The _sekhiyas_ are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a _sekhiya_ is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-as: There are seven _adhikaraṇasamathadhamma_, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the _Samathakkhandhaka_. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (_uposatha_).
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-as1: A legal issue can only be resolved if all those concerned are present during the process. In addition the procedure must comply with all aspects of monastic law.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-as2: If a nun is known for her clarity of memory, any accusations against her may be settled through that nun declaring her innocence based on her memory of the relevant events.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-as3: A nun who is insane is not responsible for her own offenses. Any offenses she may have committed while insane can be cleared through a declaration of past insanity.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-as4: All offenses, except those entailing expulsion, should be cleared by making amends in the appropriate manner.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-as5: A dispute that drags on without resolution may be settled through majority vote.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-as6: A nun who is intractable in regard to the offenses she has committed may be subject to an act of censure.
pli-tv-bi-pm-blurbs:pli-tv-bi-pm-as7: If a dispute involves a number of offenses on both sides, and the Order considers that dealing with all the offenses in the usual manner is likely to lead to harshness or schism, then the Order may decide to do a procedure whereby all the offenses are cleared. Offenses that cannot be cleared in this way are those entailing expulsion and suspension, as well as any offenses that involve lay people.
